title: LIVE: AFR Energy Summit wrap up
text:
"Time isn't on our side, the transition is occurring and we need to get on with it," said Audrey Zibelman, CEO and Managing Director of the Australian Energy Market Operator.

She said Australia "can’t afford to run economy where people are worrying about keeping the lights on a hot day."

While the transition is happening she said, policy makers and politicians can't solve everything at once.

Ms Zibelman suggested "a day ahead" system where renewable energy electricity generators need to sign up with coal or gas plant to ensure power is delivered at the right time.

She said this is a way of making the market more competitive and explained how this would work: if there is a generator that pledges to deliver 200 megawatts, and they can't deliver, they should have to pay another generator to provide the energy.

"That's what the market can do for you. So we need to start thinking about how we're going to do this otherwise what happens is AEMO has to intervene.

Prioritising clear channels of energy transmission is important too. Investors spending hundreds of millions to build a plant isn't a strong investment if the power can't be transmitted to the customer.

"We need to look at these renewable energy zones" to ensure the amount of power generated can reach a customer, she said.
